sentences.sentence: There was soon light enough for them to see one another’s faces.
The Cabby( 马车夫 ) and the two children had open mouths and shining eyes;
they were drinking in the sound, and they looked as if it reminded them of something.
Uncle Andrew’s mouth was open too, but not open with joy.
He looked more as if his chin( 下巴 ) had simply dropped away from the rest of his face.
His shoulders were stooped( 下垂 ) and his knees shook. He was not liking the Voice.
If he could have got away from it by creeping( 爬行 ) into a rat’s hole, he would have done so.
But the Witch( 女巫 ) looked as if, in a way, she understood the music better than any of them.
Her mouth was shut, her lips were pressed together, and her fists were clenched( 握紧 ).
Ever since the song began she had felt that this whole world was filled with a Magic different from hers and stronger.
She hated it. She would have smashed( 粉碎 ) that whole world, or all worlds, to pieces, if it would only stop the singing.
The horse stood with its ears well forward, and twitching( 抽搐 ).
Every now and then it snorted( 发出哼声 ) and stamped the ground.
It no longer looked like a tired old cab( 出租马车 )-horse; you could now well believe that its father had been in battles.
The eastern sky changed from white to pink and from pink to gold.
The Voice rose and rose, till all the air was shaking with it.
And just as it swelled( （声音）增强 ) to the mightiest and most glorious sound it had yet produced, the sun arose.
Digory had never seen such a sun. The sun above the ruins of Charn had looked older than ours: this looked younger.
You could imagine that it laughed for joy as it came up.
And as its beams( 光芒 ) shot across the land the travelers could see for the first time what sort of place they were in.
It was a valley through which a broad, swift( 湍急的 ) river wound its way, flowing eastward( 向东 ) toward the sun.
Southward there were mountains, northward there were lower hills.
But it was a valley of mere earth, rock and water; there was not a tree, not a bush, not a blade( 叶片 ) of grass to be seen.
The earth was of many colors; they were fresh, hot and vivid( 鲜艳的 ).
They made you feel excited; until you saw the Singer himself, and then you forgot everything else.
It was a Lion. Huge, shaggy( 毛发粗长而蓬乱的 ), and bright, it stood facing the risen sun.
Its mouth was wide open in song and it was about three hundred yards away.
“This is a terrible world,” said the Witch( 女巫 ). “We must fly at once. Prepare the Magic.”
“I quite agree with you, Madam( 女士 ),” said Uncle Andrew. “A most disagreeable place. Completely uncivilized( 未开化的 ). If only I were a younger man and had a gun—”
“Gosh( 天呀 )!” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “You don’t think you could shoot him, do you?”
“And who would?” said Polly.
“Prepare the Magic, old fool,” said Jadis.

“Certainly, Madam( 女士 ),” said Uncle Andrew cunningly( 狡猾地 ). “I must have both the children touching me. Put on your homeward( 回家的 ) ring at once, Digory.” He wanted to get away without the Witch( 女巫 ).
“Oh, it’s rings, is it?” cried Jadis. She would have had her hands in Digory’s pocket before you could say knife, but Digory grabbed( 抓住 ) Polly and shouted out:
“Take care. If either of you come half an inch nearer, we two will vanish( 消失 ) and you’ll be left here for good.
Yes. I have a ring in my pocket that will take Polly and me home.
And look! My hand is just ready. So keep your distance. I’m sorry about you.” He looked at the Cabby( 马车夫 ), “and about the horse, but I can’t help that.
As for you two,” he looked at Uncle Andrew and the Queen “you’re both magicians, so you ought to enjoy living together.”
“’Old your noise, everyone,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “I want to listen to the music.”
For the song had now changed.
The Lion was pacing to and fro( 来回地 ) about that empty land and singing his new song.
It was softer and more lilting( 欢快的 ) than the song by which he had called up the stars and the sun; a gentle, rippling( 潺潺流水般的 ) music.
And as he walked and sang the valley grew green with grass.
It spread out from the Lion like a pool.
It ran up the sides of the little hills like a wave.
In a few minutes it was creeping( 爬行 ) up the lower slopes( 山坡 ) of the distant mountains, making that young world every moment softer.
The light wind could now be heard ruffling( 使起伏不平 ) the grass. Soon there were other things besides grass.
The higher slopes( 山坡 ) grew dark with heather( 帚石楠，植物 ).
Patches( 小块 ) of rougher and more bristling( 浓密的 ) green appeared in the valley.
Digory did not know what they were until one began coming up quite close to him.
It was a little, spiky( 尖尖的 ) thing that threw out dozens of arms and covered these arms with green and grew larger at the rate of about an inch every two seconds.
There were dozens of these things all round him now.
When they were nearly as tall as himself he saw what they were. “Trees!” he exclaimed( 惊呼 ).
The nuisance( 讨厌的事 ) of it, as Polly said afterward( 之后 ), was that you weren’t left in peace to watch it all.
Just as Digory said “Trees!” he had to jump because Uncle Andrew had sidled( 悄悄地走 ) up to him again and was going to pick his pocket( 扒窃 ).
It wouldn’t have done Uncle Andrew much good if he had succeeded,
for he was aiming at the right-hand pocket because he still thought the green rings were “homeward( 回家的 )” rings.
But of course Digory didn’t want to lose either.
“Stop!” cried the Witch( 女巫 ). “Stand back. No, further back.
If anyone goes within ten paces of either of the children, I will knock out his brains.”
She was poising( 握稳 ) in her hand the iron bar that she had torn off the lamp-post, ready to throw it.
Somehow no one doubted that she would be a very good shot.
“So!” she said. “You would steal back to your own world with the boy and leave me here.”
Uncle Andrew’s temper( 脾气 ) at last got the better of his fears. “Yes, Ma’am, I would,” he said. “Most undoubtedly I would.
I should be perfectly in my rights.
I have been most shamefully, most abominably( 极差地 ) treated.
I have done my best to show you such civilities as were in my power.
And what has been my reward? You have robbed—I must repeat the word—robbed a highly respectable jeweler( 珠宝商 ).
You have insisted on( 坚持 ) my entertaining( 招待 ) you to an exceedingly( 极其 ) expensive, not to say ostentatious( 铺张的 ), lunch,
though I was obliged( 强迫 ) to pawn( 典当 ) my watch and chain in order to do so
(and let me tell you, Ma’am, that none of our family have been in the habit of frequenting pawnshops( 当铺 ), except my cousin Edward, and he was in the Yeomanry).
During that indigestible( 难消化的 ) meal—I’m feeling the worse for it at this very moment—your behavior and conversation attracted the unfavorable attention of everyone present.
I feel I have been publicly disgraced( 丢脸 ).
I shall never be able to show my face in that restaurant again.
You have assaulted( 袭击 ) the police. You have stolen—”
“Oh shut up, Governor, do shut up,” said the Cabby( 马车夫 ). “Watching and listening’s the thing at present; not talking.”
There was certainly plenty to watch and to listen to.
The tree which Digory had noticed was now a full-grown beech( 山毛榉，植物 ) whose branches swayed( 摇摆 ) gently above his head.
They stood on cool, green grass, sprinkled( 散布 ) with daisies( 雏菊 ) and buttercups( 毛茛，植物 ).
A little way off, along the river bank, willows( 柳树 ) were growing.
On the other side tangles( 一丛丛 ) of flowering currant( 醋栗，植物 ), lilac( 丁香，植物 ), wild rose, and rhododendron( 杜鹃花 ) closed them in.
The horse was tearing up delicious mouthfuls of new grass.
All this time the Lion’s song, and his stately( 器宇轩昂的 ) prowl( 游走 ), to and fro( 来回地 ), backward( 向后地 ) and forward, was going on.
What was rather alarming was that at each turn he came a little nearer.
Polly was finding the song more and more interesting because she thought she was beginning to see the connection between the music and the things that were happening.

When a line of dark firs( 冷杉 ) sprang up on a ridge( 山脊 ) about a hundred yards away she felt that they were connected with a series of deep, prolonged( 悠长的 ) notes( 音符 ) which the Lion had sung a second before.
And when he burst into a rapid series of lighter notes( 音符 ) she was not surprised to see primroses suddenly appearing in every direction.
Thus, with an unspeakable thrill( 激动 ), she felt quite certain that all the things were coming (as she said) “out of the Lion’s head.”
When you listened to his song you heard the things he was making up: when you looked round you, you saw them.
This was so exciting that she had no time to be afraid.
But Digory and the Cabby( 马车夫 ) could not help feeling a bit nervous as each turn of the Lion’s walk brought him nearer.
As for Uncle Andrew, his teeth were chattering( 打颤 ), but his knees were shaking so that he could not run away.

article_info.previous: 利用戒指的魔力，女巫一行人到了“虚无”这个地方，远处传来的悠扬的歌声引起了所有人的注意。

article_info.share_words: The lion was pacing to and fro about that empty land and singing his new song. It was softer and more lilting than the song by which he had called up the stars and the sun: a gentle, rippling music.

question.cn: 女巫喜欢她听到的声音吗？
question.en: Did the Witch like the voice she heard?

analysis: 文中提到：“But the Witch look as if, in a way, she understood the music better than any of them. Her mouth was shut, her lips were pressed together, and her fists were clenched.”由此可知，当女巫听到这个声音，她咬紧嘴唇，握紧拳头，说明她不喜欢她所听到的声音，因此算B。

question.cn: 根据本章内容，是谁发出了这美妙的乐声？
question.en: According to the passage, who made this beautiful music?

analysis: 文中提到：“It was a Lion. Huge, shaggy, and bright, it stood facing the risen sun. Its mouth was wide open in song and it was about three hundred yards away.”由此前后联系起来，是狮子发出了刚才那个声音，因此选A。

question.cn: 为什么Uncle Andrew鬼鬼祟祟地走向Digory?
question.en: Why did Uncle Andrew sidle up to Digory?

options.en: Because he wanted to kill Digory.
Because he wanted to steal Digory's rings.
Because he wanted to criticize Digory.

analysis: 文中提到：“He had to jump because Uncle Andrew had sidled up to him again and was going to pick his pocket... because he still thought the green rings were ‘homeward’ rings.”由此得知，Uncle Andrew鬼鬼祟祟地走向Digory的目的是伺机偷取Digory的戒指，因此选B。

question.cn: 为什么Uncle Andrew想要偷绿戒指？
question.en: Why did Uncle Andrew want to steal the green ring？

options.cn: 因为他想回到他自己的世界。
options.en: Because he wanted to go back to his own world.
Because he wanted to sell the ring.
Because he wanted to give it to the Witch.

analysis: 文中提到当女巫询问Uncle Andrew：“You would steal back to your own world with the boy and leave me here.”Uncle Andrew回答道：“Yes, Ma’am, I would.”因此选A。

question.cn: Polly发现狮子歌声里最有意思的是什么？
question.en: What was the most interesting thing Polly found about the Lion’s sound?

options.cn: 她发现狮子的歌声可以创造生命。
options.en: She found that lion’s sound could create lives.

options.cn: 她发现狮子的歌声没有任何意义。
options.en: She found that lion’s sound had no meaning.

options.cn: 她发现狮子的歌声可以让她想睡。
options.en: She found that lion’s sound could make her sleepy.

analysis: 文中提到：“She felt that they were connected with a series of deep, prolonged notes which the Lion had sung a second before. . . when you listened to his song you heard the things he was making up.”由此可知狮子的歌声可以创造出生命，因此选A。
